qas.question: Less sophisticated systems might just support a TZ value with one start rule and how many end rules?
When must TZ values be changed on an older system?
What does the TZ value EST5EDT,M3.2.0/02:00,M11.1.0/02:00 specify?

answers.text: time for the eastern United States starting in 2007

qas.question: What years will a new TZ value apply to?
What's might a new TZ value mishandle when it changes with new DST rules?

context: Older or stripped-down systems may support only the TZ values required by POSIX, which specify at most <a0_0>one<a0_0/> start and end rule explicitly in the value. For example, TZ='EST5EDT,M3.2.0/02:00,M11.1.0/02:00' specifies <a2_0>time for the eastern United States starting in 2007<a2_0/>. Such a TZ value must be changed <a1_0>whenever DST rules change<a1_0/>, and the new value applies to <a3_0>all years<a3_0/>, mishandling some <a4_0>older timestamps<a4_0/>.
